Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: The single core Medfield has hyperthreading. For the phone/tablet applications it seems to scale nicely so performance is somewhere between a one and two core CPU. I think it is about 1.6x a single core. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper_threading A number of the issues of the CISC vs RISC PC wars will repeat themselves again. Unless things have changed dramatically, ARM code size will be about 40% larger than the same Atom version. That leads to a lower code cache miss rate and fewer memory operations. More of the combined LLC will be available for data. That leads to fewer data cache misses. The buffers driving the buses to the memory consume lots of power. It is very hard to distill the argument down to a frequency vs frequency comparison. There are a number of issues on both sides that muddy the comparison. I would probably look at the operation and standby times of systems built on both chips. There is a lot of discussion about process benefits. Those who say that processes are equal are in the minority. With 22nm Ivy Bridge hitting 50% of Intel CPU shipments this quarter, it shows how fast Intel can convert and ramp. It seems to be several times as fast as TSMC is doing.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: Medfield based Lava Xolo has half the normalized battery life of an A5 based IPhone4s on web browsing workloads.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: Yep. Lava web browsing on 3g net is only about half. Battery life while talking, performance loads and many of the other test results, however, are in the same range. Not the best but not the universal half. Page 6 Battery Life Lava Xolo X900 Review - The First Intel Medfield Phone by Brian Klug on 4/25/2012 http://www.anandtech.com/print/5770

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: Other ARM chips can't match the A5 performance either which suggests it is not the application processor that is causing this difference. Intel will reduce the power/core by having a new Atom design built with all the experience of the first generation and by having very specialized LP version of the already very low leakage 22nm process. Since Pentium 4 Intel have been exemplary in producing great new designs and I expect Silvermont to be no different. Medfield was just a toe in the water but Silvermont will show what Intel can really do on a very advanced mobile chip as if their future depended on it and in effect their future large growth does. If you expect only incremental progress you will probably be very disappointed, I expect new bar raising on both performance and power usage.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: The point I'm making is Intel is not uniquely positioned to make greater progress than competitors on either architecture or process. Both camps will make about the same amount of progress if you buy the law of averages. I would tilt the balance in favor of the ARM camp because they have much more momentum in low power. Medfield is not a first generation design. They've been pitching "low-power IA" for some time now.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: 'Medfield is not a first generation design.' Its architectural core is even if the chip energy management has evolved over different SoC generations. That us why you can pick any Atom from any series (N,D,Z) and rely on very similar performance characteristics. ' Both camps will make about the same amount of progress if you buy the law of averages. I would tilt the balance in favor of the ARM camp because they have much more momentum in low power.' The law of averages has not helped AMD much ;-). The fact that ARM has had that momentum for so long does not imply there is much low hanging fruit left for them whereas Atom was Intel's first serious attempt at a low power architecture. I would put more credence on Intel's architects making progress than any architectural team in the ARM world which is split up amongst ARMH, QCOM, AAPL, NVDA etc.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: ARMH, QCOM, AAPL, NVDA are all building the next generation of chips that have been validated in the market by high volume sales. You couldn't say that of Medfield. Intel is shooting at a moving target. Raw architecture and process optimization don't necessarily translate into chips that your customers could fly with. I suspect Motorola was arm-twisted into building Medfield based phones and even they are not exclusive Intel.

Topic.Title: Intel Moves Into the Mobile Market

Message.Msg: It comes down to a question of will at some point. How badly does Intel want to join in the smartphone/tablet market? Intel is focusing billions of dollars of resources into CAPEX just to get them to a point of not only producing 14nm smart phone chips but in numbers that are mind blowing. Had ARM successfully transitioned into 28nm this year to the point that most of the cutting edge phones on the market would currently be using them I would have agreed with your statement of ARM momentum. They are having problems ramping up production of sub-30nm. Intel can afford to make better products for a cheaper price. Then they can afford to get sales people out to get design wins of new products using Intel. Unlike the PC industry the phone industry can be dominated by the right contracts with a few key suppliers. But, let's just imagine that Intel is locked out of Samsung and Apple. Let's just say they would be exclusively ARM until their last day in business. Intel can make design reference phones for all the large mobile carriers. They can go to AT&T and tell them how to get a $150 Intel phone. AT&T can be in charge of pushing out updates on their schedule. They can offer it for less (free with contract). Intel can help pay for co-branded advertising. There are so many things that Intel can do that ARM cannot do. It's no longer a question of "if" Intel wants in at the table, it's more of a question of how many seats it will take. If you are betting on ARM you are backing the wrong team.

RT is worse off than I thought! BTW, who is anxiously waiting for any Windows 8 devices?

Message.Title: Just A Weekend Thought
Message.Msg: With summer vacation continuing next week, expect volume to stay very thin. Both the DJIA and the S&P 500 are now only a hair under their multiyear highs. The magnet from those highs is likely to bring the indexes to their new multiyear highs. Should the breakout happen in a decisive fashion, expect bears to capitulate. Complacency is on the rise. But with the central bankers having their hands out ready to stop any fall, downside is limited. The melt-up could go a little further. have a nice weekend
